newsitem.title: SAUDI ARABIA: King tells haj pilgrims Saudi committed to peace.
newsitem.headline: King tells haj pilgrims Saudi committed to peace.

text.p: Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah told Moslems at the haj pilgrimage that the kingdom was committed to comprehensive Middle East peace, the official Saudi Press Agency (SPA) said.

In an annual joint message to pilgrims, they stressed on Friday that Saudi Arabia was continuing its support "for a comprehesive and just peace that lifts the oppression from the oppressed and returns occupied Arab land to the people of Palestine, Syria and Lebanon", SPA reported.
King Fahd and Crown Prince Abdullah said the kingdom had repeatedly condemned Israel's building of settlements in Jerusalem and any moves against the rights of its inhabitants.

"The stand of the kingdom towards Jerusalem and the construction of Jewish settlements in the city is very clear. We condemn all illegal acts in Jerusalem leading to a change in its status quo and violation of the legitimate rights of its people," SPA reported them as saying.
The Saudi leaders also called on Moslems to look to the Koran to settle their differences and urged the Islamic world to boost cooperation.
Some two million Moslems performed this year's haj which ended on Friday.
But the pilgrimage was rattled by a fierce fire that swept through 70,000 tents at a haj compound on Tuesday, killing 343 people and injuring 1,290.
